citations.narrative:
As of December 2022, the capuchin enclosures were set up so that the two outdoor areas were sharing a chain link
fence. A metal mesh was placed on the connecting fence to prevent the two groups from interacting with each other. On
two occasions, first in July and then in September 2023, the same male capuchin was found with injuries to his fingers.
The second incident required medical intervention, but the capuchin recovered well with no lasting effects. The exact
cause of injury could not be determined. The facility could not find any sharp point within the enclosure and deduced that
the capuchin’s fingers were most likely injured by him forcing the tips through the mesh separating the two enclosures
allowing a primate in the adjacent enclosure to damage them. The enclosure did not protect the capuchin from injury.
Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be designed and constructed to protect the animals from injury and contain
them securely. Corrective measures were implemented prior to inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
